It seems perfect. For performances , story, cinematography. For lovely mix of love story and ordinary life aspects. For a great chemistry between Eastwood and Streep. And for the wise science to escape to comfortable cliches. Romance and little more. Almost a cup of black tea.

Clint Eastwood directs and stars in this romance about a brief encounter between a photographer for National Geographic and a lonely immigrant woman (Meryl Streep, given another accent to try for size).  It is a flashback story, triggered by Streep's children sorting out her belongings years later when she has died, and we see just what this brief relationship meant to her.  The film lingers on the objects around the lead characters to put across the experience of their attraction to each other.What could have been preposterous works really well  the couple dance together in the kitchen, they go sight-seeing, they obviously get along. The story just about sweeps you along, even though you know it is silly, and it is nice to see Eastwood in a quieter role after all the shoot-fests he's famous for.  Just the pleasure of watching these two versatile actors together is worth any clunky scenes in The Bridges of Madison County'.  A film anyone with a touch of romance in their soul can truly appreciate.

An amazing movie that will.move you! Meryl Streep with the way she move her hands and with one look can tell a story with her eyes.Eastwood directing and acting. He is an actor that will too tell the story well when acting but his directing really sets the scene for Streep.Not seen this yet? It's a must!

reviews.review_title: This cannot be accepted as representative of true romance
reviews.content: My wife and myself have just watched this film on TCM. We are both in our seventies, and agree nearly completely with the criticisms made of it here in the user reviews, which we usually read after we have watched a film. Interestingly, reading these reviews in chronological order, it seems that the ones over the last few years are nearly all favorable, which says much about present day morals and understanding of mature adult relationships, we think.One reviewer says that he gives the film a zero, but his wife gives it ten, and we suspect that reviews which are favorable are mostly from women.Francesca never matured emotionally. Her teenage longing for excitement and romance may well have been totally repressed, even to a state of not consciously recognizing her condition, but we do not think this excuses her from her infidelity. Her after-death confessions to her children were wicked, and they should not have granted her wish to have her ashes scattered off the bridge. Respecting their father, they should have had her buried in the plot reserved for her, where they could both then attend the graves of their parents, if they so wished.As has been pointed out many times in these reviews, Robert was a deceitful womanizer and a loner, and Francesca had no assurance that he would be faithful to her if she had run away with him. The only thing which held these two pathetic creatures together was lust, not love.Sadly lacking in the film was any real indication of the relationship between Francesca and her husband. At the beginning of their relationship, there must have been romance and excitement for both of them in war-torn Italy. They probably got married in Italy, and she would look forward to further excitement in the land of opportunity, not realizing that he was really only a quiet country boy who just wanted to get back to his ancestral farm and work it until his dying day. He was perceptive, as on his death-bed he seemed to know that he had not been a totally fulfilling husband.We give this film a rating of two, because it has stimulated thought and conversation, but to class it as a romance is absurd.

Yes, technically the movie was well filmed and had some lovely cinematography, but it was also obviously written to tug on the heartstrings of those viewers easily given to sentimental mush.***Spoiler to follow***My biggest beef is with the story, itself, and the message it gives. Here we have a middle-aged bored housewife who's going through a midlife crisis and longs for some excitement. So what else is new? I'm middle-aged and I'd like some excitement, too, please. Enter our rugged traveling photographer, Clint Eastwood, and, a few screws later, our housefrau has now found the love of her eternal life????? Of course she's horny for him: he's exciting, adventurous, a deep-thinker, poetic - but very selfish and crappy family material. Meanwhile, her devoted husband of umpteen years, who is not abusive in any way and has stood by her through thick and thin takes the back seat because he's...well, boring. As a married man of 10 years with 2 children, I guess this gives me free license to dump my wife and kids if I suddenly wake up one morning and find them tedious in comparison to some hot new chick that really turns me on. It also makes me feel really good to know that, right now, my wife is probably fantasizing about dumping me for some rugged, exciting, outdoorsy type.This is basically another Jack and Rose Titanic situation, where the audience is deliberately kept from the reality of what would happen if these two shmucks really did get together. Namely, Clint would dump Meryl when he got tired of having sex with her or Meryl would dump Clint when she finally figured out what a twit he was. Well, it's nice to know that they will be stuck with each other for eternity - under a bridge of Madison County.

This is a wonderful wonderful movie.. I am one of those hard heartned people who NEVER is touched by any cheesy Hollywood romance scene... I almost NEVER cry during a movie...and the ONLY other movie I cried was Bjorks Dancer in the Dark. But this movie was so well done. So simple and realistic and un sappy... that it actually moved me. reviews.review_title: The author of the book was a professor of mine.....
reviews.content: When I was a senior in college, Robert James Waller taught what was to be his last business course at UNI. I was fortunate enough to have been a part of that class. He was leaving teaching for a "special project". Little did I know, it turned out to be the book that later turned into a movie.The similarities between Robert Kincaid and Mr. Waller are many. Mr. Waller was a photographer and a musician with a way about him that I have yet to see again in my 51 years, so similar to the character in the movie. He was those things in addition to being a business consultant and college professor with notable accomplishments. Some of my fondest memories from class were not only his lessons, but also being able to enjoy classes where he shared his photography and music.When I graduated from college, I was given a questionnaire to fill out. One of the questions was along the lines of something that I would never change about my college experience. My response was how fortunate I was to attend Mr. Waller's class and how I had hoped he would not leave. Alas, he went on to further success.I watched the movie last night with my wife, who had not seen it yet. I was flooded with many wonderful memories of Mr. Waller along with a good friend of mine that played in the band in the road house scene. While the son and daughter characters in the movie are a tad hokey, I think the movie still stands up.R. I. P. Mr. Waller, you are missed by many.

reviews.review_title: Someone please find me a man that doesn't slam the screen door!
reviews.content: I love Clint Eastwood but am very disappointed he decided to put out such a sentimental, immoral piece of drivel. Yes, Clint and Meryl play their roles expertly and are determined to draw the viewer into their illicit, adulterous affair. And yes, we are expected to forgive them this horrible sin, because, gee, she's bored and lonely and has given up her dreams. And he is so exciting, and rugged and handsome. And don't forget he doesn't slam the screen door! That's the ultimate criteria when choosing a soul mate. Who could blame her for cheating on her tedious, sad little husband. Oh yes, and because she ultimately DOESN'T leave her husband in the end, she is quite heroic and self-sacrificing. Give me a break!I especially found the plot device of using Francesca's adult children to reveal the story very creepy. I can't imagine, as a mom, divulging with lurid details an affair I had many years prior that meant I had cheated on their father. Who does this? The most ridiculous part is when Francesca writes to her daughter in the letter something to the effect: "Remember when you wanted to borrow my new dress and I wouldn't let you? That would have been like loaning you my wedding dress.".... gag....gag.... Are you kidding me? How sick! And the daughter just smiles. I would've have been completely grossed out. If I remember the scene, I think the daughter is at the cedar chest and even holds or stokes the dress and then puts it on. "OK mom, so THIS is the dress you wore the night you cheated on my dad - how beautiful!!! I must put it on!" ...Ewwwwwww!!!!! It would be like Monica Lewinsky's daughter one day being proud to put on the infamous blue dress!HELLO Hollywood, please quit trying to glamorize adultery and get us to fall for your trash just because "it's SO romantic" and you guess we are all so stupid. I love a good cry and sweeping love story as good as the next gal , but I don't need it at the expense of having to suspend my morals to do so.

I'm biased. I dont think Streep is a good actress. I realize most people will disagree but compare her to Clint who goes thru his role effortlessly and see how you always know that Streep is acting.Technically she's good, but there's no real huanity in her. It's all fake.Nicole Kidman is such a better actress. So anway, I was bored out of my mind and BTW the movie isnt even all that well written.

Clint stars and directs this powerful sliding doors-style love story about a middle aged couple who experience once in a lifetime love over four short days. Clint is wonderful as the drifter photographer with the effortless Eastwood charm, while Meryl delivers yet another acting masterclass. Beautifully acted, directed and shot 8/10.

THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY is something different from Eastwood as star and director: a slow-burning romance, told in flashback, that takes place over just four days. It's reminiscent of BRIEF ENCOUNTER but otherwise very '90s in feel, all homely and warm and with good-natured people throughout. If I'm honest, I found it all more than a little dull, although the naturalistic performances are fine. Streep's Italian immigrant character smacks of cliche and, although Eastwood is as charming as ever, he doesn't seem to have much drive here. This reminded me of THE POSTMAN ALWAYS RINGS TWICE but without the plot and suspense.

I love this movie. Meryl Streep is at her very best as the Italian housewife Francesca on an Iowa farm. Her husband and children ignore her and her deepest dreams have been unfulfilled. The family has gone to the fair, leaving her alone. By chance, she meets a roving photographer (Clint Eastwood) taking photos of the nearby bridges. She assists him and the have an immediate bond. They both find their soulmates but only have four days to be together until her family returns. What will she do? Leave? Stay? This movie reaches deeply into who we are as people and what we want. It is beautifully directed by Eastwood, and he centers wonderfully on Streep's Francesca, even though his performance is outstanding. It's a lovely , romantic film and a favorite.

reviews.review_title: An Affair During The State Fair
reviews.content: Clint Eastwood celebrated his 65th Birthday just days before the release of this movie. His 19th movie as director is a very good drama that shows how much he had matured as a film director at this juncture. Meryl Streep, 19 years his junior, is an Iowa farm housewife who packs her kids off to the state fair with dad to enter their prize cow in a contest. Little does anyone suspect, she would encounter a man, a National Geographic Photographer covering bridges.The weakest part of this film is the beginning where the kids are grown up and at moms after she died wondering why she suddenly wants to be cremated. This is the weakest part of the film. Streep & Eastwood & the central story are great. The film has the looks of a picture post card. The chemistry between Eastwood & Streep is a pleasure to watch.It is a sentimental hander chief of a movie but when you have this cast, & expert work behind the camera, you just enjoy the film.

I don't normally try to characterize movies with cheap epithets like "Chick Flick" but in this case I thought it was appropriate. I found the initial premise of the film interesting and it soon drew me in (i.e. children discovering a hidden side to their mother's after her death). What initially put me off was discovering that Meryl Streep was meant to be Italian. I have great admiration for Streep as an actress but for the first part of the movie I kept trying to work out which country her accent was meant to be from. I decided eventually on Russian. Blow me down if it doesn't turn out that she's meant to be Italian. My parents are Italian and I've heard a lot of English spoken with Italian accents in my life but none of them sounded like Meryl Streep. To compound things even further she later tells Clint Eastwood that she's from a "small town" in Italy that he would never have heard of. She eventually tells him that this small town is called Bari and learns to her great surprise that he has not only heard of it but has visited it and was so entranced by what he saw that he broke his train journey and stopped there for a few days. Now I know that Americans are notoriously ignorant about other countries but Bari happens to be a large urban centre and while it has some sites worth visiting it is hardly the picturesque small town that seems to be suggested in the movie. From that point on the movie began to lose me more and more. I found it generally dull and thought it was exploiting its viewers emotions. A pity really because I thought that some of the portrayals of a marriage that were shown had great insight. I left before it finished. My wife stayed.

reviews.review_title: It's okay to cheat on your spouse if you're a woman and board.
reviews.content: I grew up on a farm in Minnesota with basically the same dynamic that this family had. I remember my mother getting this movie on cassette in the late 90s and she said that it was her favorite movie. I finally watched this movie in my early teens and I couldn't believe that this was one of my mother's favorites. The husband takes the kids with him for 4 days to do something that benefits the family and some random stranger with a camera entices Meryl streep's character somehow. I get that the woman felt empty and what not but damn.... I understand that people fall out of love but that doesn't make it okay to cheat. From what I could see the husband was a good guy and look I get it was the 60s and divorce was pretty taboo especially in the more rural areas of America at this time but having an affair was just as bad. She had other options... Sorry. When the husband was on his deathbed he looked at Meryl Streep and said basically I'm sorry I couldn't give you the life that you wanted. The guy really did love her but poor Meryl Streep had the soldier through a relationship where she didn't even love the guy... Boohoo poor Meryl Streep. I would like to also point out that if Clint Eastwood played the father that stayed home and then cheated on his wife with some photographer lady he would be chastised for it (by the audience) but for some reason it's okay when it's Meryl Streep and or female that's doing the cheating... even though I didn't like the movie for these reasons that's probably why a lot of other people actually like it. I just don't like double standards and I don't like the message that this sends out about relationships in general. Oh and about my mother... after I watched this movie I asked her if she had ever cheated on my father and she became extremely awkward and red-faced and changed the subject. so that was an awesome feeling..

When he's at his best,Eastwood is the keeper of the flame.he makes movies which hark back to the good old days of the old cinema:oldies but goldies."The unforgiven" brought back the western as it used to be;"midnight in the garden..." conjured the Tennessee Williams atmosphere;and "Madison" ,these are the days of Douglas Sirk,"all that heaven allows"With Sirk in "all that heaven allows",Eastwood shares the passion for nature,for this "middle of nowhere" where Streep lives.The cinematography is luminous,and Eastwood lovingly films both the landscapes and the wonderful actress he chose .At the beginning of the movie ,she's a housewife,almost a matrone,and little by little,like a delicate flower,she blossoms and becomes a wonderful woman.It was a very good idea to display the romance as a long flashback,a thing of the past.These foolish things which Streep hides in her chest were the thrill of it all,these memories that make a life worth living. For Eastwood -who 's like a rolling stone,without a home,but has been in the whole world- and Streep -stuck in the middle of nowhere-,this brief encounter will enlighten their whole life,and we feel happy that such things happen from time to time in a world so cold.And if you do not shed a tear during the last sequence,you've got to have a heart of stone
Let me tell you Clint Eastwood and Meryl Streep have such great chemistry. i was hooked from start to finish.

I was surprised by several elements of the movie - Clint directs with more sensitivity than I would have thought possible and his own portrayal of Robert is very good also.  I admire Meryl Streep more than any other actor and she is very good in this, too.  You can feel the sexual tension between the actors and that is when the movie is at its best - the little moments when dialogue is at a minimum but there is a lot going on. It was also nice to see a couple of approximately the same age, and also nice that Meryl's husband wasn't made out to be this total jerk, thereby giving a segment of the audience the reason to understand why she is having an affair. Sometimes things just happen between people and that's what I got out of this movie.

"The Bridges of Madison County" is a leisurely-paced, finely-tuned  romantic drama beautifully orchestrated by director/actor Clint Eastwood, with a transcending performance by Meryl Streep.Based on Robert James Waller's surprisingly successful novella, this project has Clint Eastwood straying from his formulaic action material and winding up with one of the most lyrical, passionate dramas to come out recently. Who knew Eastwood could aim so perfectly for the heart without the help of a gun and holster.In adapting this rather prosaic piece of prose for the screen, Eastwood shrewdly (and graciously) shifts the point of view from Robert Kincaid to Francesca Johnson.  With Meryl Streep as its primary focus, how could anything go wrong?  Streep is simply luminous here as the  foreign-born Iowa farmwife and mother consigned to a life of drudgery.  Her family away for the week, she happens upon a handsome, worldly photographer briefly in town scouting out locations for his next National Geographic spread.  What results is a beautifully mature story of spiritual and unconditional love. Eastwood himself displays a rare, vulnerable side as the taciturn Kincaid who has grown accustomed to a solitary, self-serving existence.  The chemistry between Eastwood and Streep is surprisingly potent and ultimately moving, a real tribute to their disparate talents.    With subtle nuance, we slowly become familiar with these two unlikely strangers in the night.  A harmless lunch...a cozier dinner...revealing conversation...a slight brush of the shoulder...the casual adjustment of a shirt collar...a spontaneous mating dance.  Once their true feelings finally come to the surface, we feel for them and understand and rationalize their attraction.  This is absolutely crucial in maintaining the beauty of the romance for it must reroute the obvious appearance of a housewife conducting an adulterous affair with some fly-by-night Romeo.  Significantly, Francesca's husband is not portrayed here as an abusive lout deserving of such betrayal.  He is simply a remote, unresponsive farmer who has settled routinely into mid-life -- still devoted to his family.The perfervid affair, of course, is beset with feelings of guilt, anguish and fear, but never regret.  Ever mindful of small-town gossip (one cruel restaurant scene has a known scarlet' woman openly ostracized by its patrons and employees), the couple find out-of-the-way places to go to enjoy their brief time together, while faced with the dilemma of their futures. The climactic scene in the truck with the tormented Francesca gripping the door handle, torn between staying in the truck with her unsuspecting husband or fleeing to Eastwood in the automobile stopped just ahead of them is one of the most searing, agonizing screen moments ever experienced by this viewer.A minor drawback to the film is the "present day" subplot device, which reappears sporadically and bookends the affair seen in flashback.  These scenes involve Francesca's two surviving children coming to terms with the discovery of their mother's past affair via letters, diaries and mementos purposely left to be read upon her death.  These segments are integral, to be sure, but awkwardly presented and annoyingly intrusive.Known for his deep love of jazz, Eastwood incorporates a wonderfully lush, often bluesy score, littered with familiar classics, notably by the late, great Dinah Washington, whose exquisite version of "I'll Close My Eyes" is a must for every music library, and Johnny Hartman, whose "For All We Know" highlights the lovers' initial encounter.  "The Bridges of Madison County," despite its deliberately languid pace, is an enduring wallow for incurable romantics everywhere.  Simply, it is an affair to remember.

reviews.review_title: As Effective As It Is Simple
reviews.content: One of the joys of Clint Eastwood's oeuvre is that, besides his tough-guy cop or western roles, he has also been involved (acting, directing, or both) in a plethora of "simple" films. Not simple in the sense of "bad" or "dumb", mind you, but simple in that they don't really on a ton of other components besides a good story, solid characters, and terrific acting. Those three things are exactly what are featured in "The Bridges of Madison County".For a basic plot summary, this movie tells the story of Francesca (Meryl Streep), an Iowa housewife--originally from Italy--who had/has big dreams in life but has "settled" for a husband and two children. On one rare occasion where she is left alone for a few days, photographer Robert Kincaid (Eastwood) stumbles upon her farmstead looking for directions. What follows is a whirlwind romance in which both parties learn each other's deepest desires and must make tough decisions before "the family" returns home.Because "Bridges" is such a dialogue-heavy film, the characters have to be absolutely spot-on in terms of writing, and that's exactly what happens here. Truly the best scenes of the entire experience are Francesca & Robert just sitting at the dinner table talking to each other. Universal (and timeless) themes such as loneliness, entrapment, wanderlust, and passion are discussed, and thus there is something for nearly every viewer to identify with.Incredible acting is a "must" too, of course, to carry all that dialogue, and does it really get much better than Eastwood & Streep? While seemingly an odd fit for each other at first, they are both so good at their craft that it becomes easy to understand what is drawing these two characters together and the tornado of emotions the relationship produces.I also liked how the story is framed in a flashback reference, where Francesca's children are all discovering this for the first time themselves by reading their mother's old diaries. This framing mechanism lends even more importance to the "chance encounter" (especially at the beginning of the film), as viewers already know this will become a momentous period in Francesca's life.It would be easy for modern film-goers to discard or dismiss "Bridges of Madison County" as "too slow". To be honest, despite being a huge fan of Eastwood's work, it even took me a long time (and a specific recommendation) to get to this one. However, that was an enormous injustice to the story, acting, and direction present here. If you want to see how Eastwood honed his emotional-movie craft to later make masterpieces such as "Million Dollar Baby", "Gran Torino", or "Changeling", one could make a case that all starts with "Bridges of Madison County".

A most surprising approach of mid-life love for a mother and wife, though seen by a male director apparently well supported or supplemented by some women in the team. What happens if for four days you are alone, but not abandoned, and meet a man that reveals to you that there can be some new love in your life even though this life of yours is satisfied, happy, well-balanced and characterized by no particular need nor want, nor even, as for that, wish, except maybe the desire to listen to and enjoy some classical music, some opera singing  and it could be anything at all  which is not appreciated by the other members of the family ? That is rather light as for discontentment or dissatisfaction. A short-lived love affair develops during and over these four days and you are confronted to the need to make a decision. The situation has already been considered by many and in many films. You break off and away and let yourself go with that love affair. Then later on you regret what you have lost in the process. Or you resist and do not yield and you regret all your life what you have not done. In both case you enjoy what you have taken or kept and you are divided between the two sides of your decision : does what I have taken or kept balance what I have rejected, refused or let go ? The film is thus not particularly innovative by its theme. Yet it has a special perfume, fragrance. What is it ? Certainly not the reaction of the children when they learn about it after your death. Their reactions are predictable and even superficial. The special value of this film is in fact in the two actors and the way they embody, with their body acting, the meeting of two potentials, the passion and the end of it, the loss of it and yet the survival of it. Apart from this marvelously well rendered flesh of the film the subject is banal. Meryl Streep particularly transcends her part and takes us into the deepest layers of her mind the way they ripple on her surface, on the surface of her body and behavior. We feel her disarray at first, her fascination then and her conservative sacrifice last in the most humane and subtle way. We are suffering and rejoicing with her and each side of her situation or decision has its lot of suffering and its lot of rejoicing. That's why this film should be kept in mind and remembered.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University of Paris Dauphine & University of Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne

reviews.review_title: An absolutely terrible "romance" movie! Is it just me, or is love no longer a part of romance?
reviews.content: Bridges of Madison County is probably the worst so-called romance movie I have ever seen. If you disagree answer these questions: Why would Francesca believe he loves her? Because of a few "lines" professing his, what? Great opportunity? His good times with her? What he said was "This kind of certainty comes but once in a lifetime." What was "certain" about it? Was it more "certain" than the wife he divorced without regret? Romance note, before you trash your life, such as it is, and run off with someone who has managed to abandon one marriage, and looks down on commitment in general, AT LEAST know that he loves you! And if he really does, he will NOT ask you to abandon your children!Another question; What exactly did he see in her? What was so special and different to leave him without sense enough to come in from the rain? Are these two "soul-mates," or is she just a woman who needs to feel loved and frustrated enough with her life to have sex with a total stranger. Was the sex sooooo life altering that he was willing to finally settle down? Passion and love, let's not confuse the two, one can last four days, perhaps a week, maybe a year... the other a lifetime. Sure, drop everything and go... he's got nothing to lose, while she'll lose what little she has. That is NOT romance, it's sad. It's insulting. The more you think about it, the more his "certainty" plays like a pickup line.And when did these DEEP LASTING emotions develop, from the 3 or 4 conversations they had? While driving along in the truck? Or was it when they were soiling the sheets in the bed where she was to sleep with her husband? Which brings me to the issue of infidelity, and the dim view of marriage in general? He doesn't seem to value it, she "suffers" through it. In this lopsided "romantic" story there's scarcely a happy couple to be found, let alone happily married one. As a GUY who LOVES romance, please, PLEASE do not accept this counterfeit tripe of an offering as real romance. Hollywood has gotten so lazy as to toss us a scrap and expect us to gobble it up as fillet! A man who asks a woman to leave her husband, and her kids who are "almost grown" is thinking of himself. A REAL man, and REAL love would offer to do whatever you wanted to make YOU happy. He would say I cannot bear to lose you BEFORE you had to have a conniption-fit in the kitchen. HE would be devastated on that last day BEFORE you served breakfast, before you did anything, and would take you by the hand and ask you to sit down, and with a lump in his throat the size of Iowa look you in the eyes and ask, "What are WE going to do?" THAT is romance. It's not a 4-day teenage fling with older actors. It's no-matter-what, 'till the end, 'till death do us part!HUSBANDS listen up! Your wives are quietly telling you something. Get busy and do your duty as a husband. Sure she's adjusted her life for you, sometimes sacrificially, but you are bound to do all within your power to see that she is happy and fulfilled! She should feel LOVED!

A terrific movie which really moved me. It really made me think of David Lean's Brief Encounter from 1945 - two people who meet for only a short time but have to part for different reasons. Meryl Streep's performance was great.

A wonderful love story... that's the way the movie was described to me.After seeing it, I couldn't understand where the love story part came in.All I saw was a woman who was unfaithful to her good husband while he was away for four days.The idea, I guess is that she was "dying inside" and that her life was empty and devoid of passion.If her marriage was that bad, she had other choices, other than violating her marriage vows.If I sound bitter, it is because this happened to me.This movie/story has a deep meaning for me, because my wife had an affair with a stranger.Now I have to question what love is, or what is meant by people when they talk about "true love".Why do people get married? Why do they take vows? I thought that I had found true love, that's why I married my wife and that's why I thought she accepted the idea to be my wife and grow old with me.So, NO... I don't see a love story here.

reviews.review_title: Meryl Streep is MAGNIFICENT. Just amazing
reviews.content: What an incredible performance by an actress. I normally don't care for Streep in today's new stuff. The WOKE movement seems to have made most people in Hollywood a little crazy now. This is a dynamite movie. Total masterpiece that cuts into your heart with emotional resonance and realism. This is how you make dramas that mean something. A job very well done 👏

reviews.review_title: Sometimes it's hard to be a woman ...............
reviews.content: Miss M.Streep is never happier than when she hides behind an accent. Here she has a cute Italian one and she cocks her head to one side a lot,smiles shyly,keeps raising her hands to her face and employs bits of "business" that clearly indicate "acting".Mr C.Eastwood on the other hand belongs to the "less is more" school and apart from the occasional wrinkling of the brow to indicate moments of high emotion is happy to rely on our perception of his screen persona in much the same way as that other great American movie invention Mr J.Wayne. Miss Streep is very beautiful(even more so near the end when she has aged realistically)but I found her transition from Italian=American earth-mother/cook/homemaker to flirty middle aged woman willing to risk everything for love decidedly unlikely. Equally Mr Eastwood's spartan independence is rather too quickly cast aside as he reverts to lovelorn adolesence in very short order. "The bridges of Madison County" was a very popular story and obviously somebody was going to make a movie of it.Because that task fell to Mr Eastwood what we have is about as good a movie as could have been made out of it.The faults lie in the original material. It is a film about love rather than sexual attraction,and in that sense is "adult".Women will find it confirms their belief that most men lack the capacity to understand what love is,men will worry that they are unable to satisfy all the criteria required by their partners. There are some lovely songs by the relatively little - known Johnny Hartman on the soundtrack that hopefully will make you go and search him out as I'm sure was Mr Eastwood's intention. He may have his critics as a director,but nobody could say his movies are all the same.

Watched this again decades later and still think it's one of the most beautiful films I've seen. Beautiful to look at as are most Eastwood films. Understated yet artistic acting. A film like this you're not likely to see much nowadays. Purely human situation with somehow finding another person you love all of a sudden, so you leave all you know or continue in a comfortable, known love. And a non perfect yet understandable ending. Real. It breaks your heart and yet brings happiness as you know they made a choice and found joy as they could with that hard decision. Great novel adapted to screen. Clint Eastwood owned this genre. Just a pure cinematic pleasure to watch.

Clint Eastwood was, and is, a lousy actor. The old actors don't just fade away-they become directors-and lousy directors at that. Clint was good during "Spaghetti Western" days when he had the least amount of spoken word and smoked reefers like no other cowboy could. Give him a dialog-he fumbles and mumbles. The screen writing is the worst. The flashbacks and the letter reading by the brother and sister team is just annoying and boring. Here is a guy from nowhere and has a fling with a married woman. Apparently he has been doing this all over the world including Bari-Itlay, India and wherever he can land himself for a Bed (read-sex) and breakfast. Unless confronted by the wives or killed by the husbands he even manages to publish few nude photos in the National Geographic. The movie is not "On Golden Pond" and these two are not Hepburn and Tracey either. Merryl Streep drifts from her Italian accent (she is the only one who has acted in this movie) to Iowa accent when not cooking country sausage for this "handy husband of three days.' A good porno movie has more entertainment value than this flick. This is an overrated movie that I had the unfortunate displeasure of seeing. I'm not the only one-one out of four thinks this movie stinks. Clint is overrated as a director and underrated as a Mayor of Carmel!

The Bridges of Madison County has two strong points : its good writing with dialogues that ring true, and a Meryl Streep-Clint Eastwood duo that works perfectly and from which a real chemistry emanates.But you just get bored to death by this almost behind closed doors romance where not much happens, the script badly lacks twists and turns, obstacles, and most importantly the rhythm is a lot too slow and that's an understatement because if the first hour is already long, the second seems endless, a real ordeal.Therefore, the credits starts rolling with a feeling of great relief for the viewer since the disinterest for this story and those character was complete.

My Rating : 8/10If you've ever been in love you will certainly enjoy and understand this little gem. Produced and directed by Clint Eastwood 'The Bridges of Madison County' explores themes of forbidden love, in this case extramarital affair with an intensity and passion that's pure magic. This is how affairs and flings happen in real life, due to human weakness. I would rather see this kind of a movie than when people act larger than life.Wonderful performances from Meryl Streep and Clint Eastwood, breathtaking chemistry and an absolute treat from beginning to finish.I highly, highly recommend it if you're reading this.
The Bridges of Madison County is one of the most tedious movies that I have ever seen. I tried to walk out but the flight attendant stopped me.

When I watch romance films, I expect a couple's chemistry and their own story building up romantically and flutteringly. However, I never expected to ponder upon love itself while watching a movie.What Francesca and Richard had can also be love, taking care of each other and building a life together. Francesca and Robert's passion, rapture, and deep understanding are a different form of love, but will it last? As Francesca said, once it lasted, it would have vanished. Whatever choice she had made, it would not be wrong, but 'we are the choices we've made'. It was all up to her, and she made a decision. However, I, like Francesca, want to know and picture with all my heart what could have been with two very much different people who had had totally different life goals, comfort and adventure. Their love being so magnificent and magical, were they willing to give up the past and and who they are for each other?For whole two hours, I feel for Francesca's love and agony to give up what's so beautiful. Streep makes it so easy and natural to put myself in her shoe and even be her, sitting right in front of the screen. Just beautiful and heartbreaking. Especially, a scene where Richard's car turns and is placed behind Robert's and the whole sequence of Streep's face, silence, Robert hanging Francesca's pendant, his waiting, and her holding the door are genius. I have never watched more poetic and beautiful scenes than this one. 'The Bridges of Madison County' is the movie, faithful to the core of cinema: story and acting."I'll only say this once. I've never said it before. But this kind of certainty comes just once in a lifetime."

Before sitting down to watch this film, you need the following equipment : a comfy armchair, a HUGE bucket to collect all your tears and a big Bath Towel to wipe your eyes ! This has to be one of the most romantic and sad films made for decades, at least since the 1940's and 1950's. Not only is it highly romantic, but the underlying eroticism will have you in a state long before the middle of the film.To start with, when the film begins, all its protagonists are already dead..... Eastwood, Streep and Streep's husband. This is already tear-provoking in itself. The film is therefore presented as a series of flashbacks in conjunction with Streep's childrens' reading of her diaries.The whole thing is very thoughtfully done, picture quality is excellent, the sets and lighting are magnificent. Streep's innocence ( "What is this passion that's invading me ???" )is extremely beautiful and natural. Eastwood plays it sober but with just the amount of passion to keep the spectator's heart pounding sufficiently quickly !!Even if you are against infidelity, it's difficult NOT to want these two to make out so to speak, as you can feel the passion "boiling up below the skin's surface" ( excuse the culinary imagery please !! )The tears really start to gush during the scene in the rain when Streep and her husband are behind Eastwood in his truck at the traffic lights -the waiting seems endless and the spectator can feel the frustration Streep is undergoing through this scene. We see Eastwood's truck turn off to the left and .......... oh ! its difficult to describe it !The final scene where the ashes are tossed into the river is of course heart-tearing and we see how Streep's children reflect on their own personal lives in the light of what they read in her diaries.It's very difficult to put into words the emotion felt on watching this film, so I'll stop here but would recommend this as one of the most romantic films of the last century which will be a source of inspiration to future generations.

reviews.review_title: Such are the dreams of the everyday housewife
reviews.content: Francesca Johnson, the Italian-born wife of a farmer in Madison County, Iowa, meets Robert Kincaid, a photographer, when he stops to ask directions. (Kincaid is on an assignment for "National Geographic" to photograph the area's famous covered bridges, hence the title of the film). A friendship grows up between them, which turns to love, and they have a brief affair while Francesca's husband Richard and her teenage children are away for a few days at the State Fair. Robert wants Francesca to leave her husband for him, but she refuses. Although she has fallen deeply in love with Robert, she is unwilling to hurt her husband and children and is afraid that her love for Robert will fade should she take the irrevocable step of ending her marriage for him.This could easily be the plot of some cheap, sentimental movie, but "The Bridges of Madison County" avoids falling into the traps of cheapness and sentimentality. Part of the reason is that it starred two of Hollywood's most talented actors, Meryl Streep as Francesca and Clint Eastwood as Robert. Eastwood was perhaps an unexpected choice, given that he was in his mid-sixties at the time and that in the past he had been most often associated with violent action films, particularly Westerns and police thrillers. In recent years, however, he has been keen to extend his range as an actor, and his role here is an example. Those who felt that he could not play a romantic hero in a film more concerned with emotions than with action were to be proved wrong. Not only is he surprisingly handsome and virile for a man of his years (how many sixty-five year-old actors would dare do a scene bare-chested as Eastwood does here?) but he brings far more tenderness and sensitivity to the role than one would expect from the man who created Dirty Harry and the High Plains Drifter.Although her previous attempt to play the heroine of a doomed romance, in "Falling in Love" about a decade earlier, was not a great success, Streep is superb as Francesca (but then, she normally is superb). Playing an Italian gives her the chance to add another to her collection of accents, but there is always more to Streep than her talent for mimicry. What convinces us that she is foreign born is not only her accent but also her mannerisms and her slight hesitancy when speaking, as though she is groping, albeit only momentarily, for words in a language not her own.Eastwood also directed the film, and the style of direction is an unusual one for a modern movie. In the thirties and forties many films were made in the "filmed theatre" style (usually forced on the directors of the day by technical limitations). Films of this type were made in a studio, generally with an indoor setting. There was more dialogue than action, and the film's literary qualities were more important than its visual ones. This style of film-making fell out of favour as the technological abilities of the cinema advanced- even when a modern film is actually based on a stage play an attempt is normally made to "open it up"- but Eastwood seems to be reverting to it here. Although there are a few outdoor scenes, including shots of one of the covered bridges which takes on an important significance, much of the action takes place in Francesca's home, particularly her kitchen, where she and Robert hold long conversations. They do not actually move into the bedroom until more than halfway through.This style of film-making has the advantage of enabling us to build up a picture of Francesca's marriage without this having to be shown in detail. In the great nineteenth-century novels of female adultery, such as "Anna Karenina", "Madame Bovary" or Fontane's "Effi Briest" it became something of a convention to depict the husband in an unflattering light, thus providing an explanation for his wife's infidelity. That convention in not followed in this film. We see little of Richard, but from what we hear of him he is neither a booby like Charles Bovary nor a cold bully like Karenin. Francesca describes him as very clean, hard-working, gentle and a good father. Yet from her conversations with Robert, we can understand why she is dissatisfied in her marriage. She married Richard shortly after the war, when he was a soldier stationed in Italy. (The film is set in the mid-sixties). It becomes clear that the young Francesca saw marriage as a means to escape from her own war-ravaged country. She seems to have fallen in love with the idea of America as a land of opportunity rather than Richard as a person, and life as Mid-West farmer's wife has not fulfilled her expectations, leaving her nostalgic for her homeland. The life of the cosmopolitan, widely-travelled Robert seems more glamorous than the one she is leading.The one thing I did not like about the film was the "framework story", set in the nineties, in which Francesca's children, now adults, discover the truth about their mother's affair from documents she leaves behind after her death. I felt that the story of Francesca and Robert was strong enough to stand on its own without this unnecessary addition, especially as the nineties subplot had a rather moralising tone at odds with that of the main story. The film as a whole, however, is very good, touching and well-made, with great insight into what Glen Campbell called "the dreams of the everyday housewife". 8/10
One of the most beautiful movies I have ever seen. For me, one of the best performances of Meryl Streep as well.

"The Bridges of Madison County" is about a miserable woman who's dying wish is to ruin any fond memories her children have of their parents. It's a brutal watch for any fan of the films of Clint Eastwood (like me). Clint does a nice job directing and his performance is strong. Meryl Streep, on the other hand, is so annoying that it's impossible to understand why Clint would be attracted to her in the first place. I first saw this movie in the theater (Fresh Meadows, NY). I've seen it a few times since. Each viewing is harder than the one before it. It was very hard for me to get to the end of it tonight. At the end of the day, "The Bridges of Madison County" is an amoral waste of time.

I'm sorry, but this movie, very simply, portrayed no grand romance. This was a woman who was married to a perfectly decent guy and who had kids. She cheated on her husband. End of story. Cheating is no romance, no matter the "sweetness" in which it is couched. I don't care about the cinematography, I don't care about the covered bridges (and the cinematography and scenery were very nice, it's just not the point). Cheating on your husband is just NOT romantic. And staying with your husband and kids is no great sacrifice. This movie disgusted me. I saw it once, when it first came out in the theaters, and my teeth still grind anytime anyone mentions it.

reviews.review_title: A masterpiece they never make any more
reviews.content: A deeply touching love story that comes but once in a lifetime, to be remembered for a lifetime. You just can't forget it, even 26 years later. Clint and Meryl made the book to come alive and even better. Everything is so down to Earth, so intelligently full of feelings that you can not but be deeply moved, and you might even cry a little bit at the end. The moral of all of it: If you were happy enough to have met the love of your life, grab it and don't ever let it go. Leave the details of your life aside. Because you will realize you were happy enough to get the one you meet only once in a lifetime and you can have him/her, which is priceless.

reviews.review_title: One of the best Eastwood films ever
reviews.content:
Usually, if I like a film, I write tons and tons about it (a bit too much sometimes, maybe) but this time I'll just make it short. This film is really incredible, because the story and the shooting is so simple, yet powerful and breathtaking. You don't believe Eastwood is a good director, try this one (or Space Cowboys). Meryl Streep is as good as (almost) ever and the supporting cast is great too. Laughs, cries and entertainment. Me and my heart were fully satisfied.
 8 out of 10

Eastwood and Streep, simply a powerful, and dynamic cast.  A simple plot, Guy meets girl, only the problem is, girl is happily married with 2 children.  Seemingly happy living the american dream until the true love of her life arrives for a brief few days and touches her for the rest of her life.  The bridges of madison county is a text book chic flick but with the added bonus of Clint Eastwood which will enable the guys to be dragged along a little less forcibly.  Perfectly direct by Eastwood himself and Streep is simply brilliant. 9/10

reviews.review_title: A Sweet and Poignant Love Story
reviews.content: An Iowa farmer's lonely Italian wife, left at home for four days while he and the children are off at the Illinois State Fair, has a torrid romance with an adventurous, globe-trotting photographer. Although he reawakens her physically and emotionally, she doesn't really believe it's true love until it is too late. What she does believe is that she has a duty to family ("the little details of her life") that eclipses her right to real happiness.One year, we went through Winterset, where the story is set, and found it to be a rather strange place. The rolling Iowa countryside, with its lush vegetation, vast, often stormy skies, and enchanting, white gravel roads, has a special charm, to be sure. But much of the state is nearly flat and it is often bleak and depressing, the unpleasant odor emanating from penned hogs and feedlots often hanging heavily in the air. And Iowans struck us as a very provincial lot -- suspicious, very nosy, and at times downright weird. In fact, some of them looked overly inbred, even potentially dangerous. The movie, to its credit, captured the essence of all that quite well. Francesca deserved more than to spend the rest of her life in such a place, and she owed it to Robert, the photographer, if to no one else. Tossing their ashes off the same bridge was a symbolic gesture, at best, and I'm afraid it was a poor substitute for the few short years they might have enjoyed together instead of just four short days in each other's arms. Even after her husband died, Francesca made only a token effort to contact Robert. While I understood her decision to stay with her family, fearing that her love for him could not last if she ran away with him and that she'd blame him for a growing sense of guilt, once her kids were gone and both she and her husband were getting older, I think she should have found him again, if only to reunite temporarily, rather than going to their respective graves never having known what might have happened. Clint Eastwood, the director, was trying to make a realistic ending, but I felt a little let down by it.That said, the love story was sweet and poignant, certain of the love scenes rather erotic, and other sequences quite moving. I particularly liked the couple's interaction on the second day, after Francesca left the note for Robert and they were hesitantly circling one another, both desperately wanting to make love. Then, the scene in the kitchen, where Francesca blew up and called Robert a shallow phony, I thought was very effective. Finally, we had the climax, where Robert stood in the rain, looking pathetic but sincere, then at the stoplight, he held up traffic for another moment, hoping Francesca would change her mind. She almost did, too, but simply couldn't tear herself away from her husband in time. To his alarm and concern, she broke down in tears as Robert turned left and rolled out of her life, forever. That was some good cinema. At the conclusion of the film, we see an encompassing view of the tidy, productive little farm where Francesca spent her life, giving everything else up to remain there. Did she make the right decision? The scenes where her grown children read her notebooks after her death, trying to understand her final wishes, could have been somewhat better but did not, to an excessive degree, detract from this otherwise excellent effort. In particular, Meryl Streep as Francesca was especially good.

This is a beautiful and touching film. I was very surprised to see this type of film from Clint Eastwood. The story is very well done and keeps you very interested. Meryl Streep does a very good and believable job in her role. Definitely recommend this film one of Eastwood's best.
I love this movie. It's a beautifully done mature romance story. EVERY woman should Have at least one GREAT romance in her life!

From location directions to picking flowers for a stranger within 10mins.The female lead is bashful and flirting with a grandpa artist within moments of their first meet and has an offer to staying for a drink, then dinner...A completely unthoughtful beginning to an overated romance.A deeper look at the academy awards this picture won is a glimpse into an agenda in full flight and the members who are often comforted by their own former family life.Thank goodness the commercial market is occupied with real people.On finer matters the philosophical vagabond who captures the attention of the bored housewife is so cliché and predictable. I wanted to stop watching a handful of times except for seeing how much worse it could get.The dialogue drags on and is tedious.The juxtaposed story timeline and flashbacking pulls us out and doesn't work well.Then of course the moral dilemma is not explored in any serious way.Rubbish.

reviews.review_title: Captivating from the start, I cried.
reviews.content: The Story is beautiful, the acting made me forget who the actors are actually. I loved the slowness, the dialogues, the mood. I cried rivers.

reviews.review_title: A romantic masterpiece that says it all!
reviews.content: The movie is so brilliantly made to deliver the message of what you want versus what you should do. I guess this role wasn't difficult to Streep in its essence as she played it already with Robert Deniro in Falling in Love but there was a challenge in this role and it is unfair not to be able to see it as a viewer! The challenge was for Meryle who is in her 40s to act as the teenage who fell in love and found the passion that she had never felt before in such an age and still be lovable to the conservative viewer. I, for one, loved her so much and wasn't intimidated by anything in the way she acted. I was totally compassionate with the character and I have to say that many of the comments didn't quite understand the character. It all lies in the scene where she says to Eastwood that she hoped she didn't bore him with her stupid chatting and he replies back that he could never think of her that way and that she was a smart woman. It's at the moment that she falls in love with him because she had lost her wit in the simple life of the simple man she got married. Just amazing! The story talks about the kind of love that you find once in your life with only one person who can get out the real you and make you feel your importance which life tends to bury down with its different loads.The movie had so many deep and beautiful scenes, particularly the scene where Francesca is in the car with her husband and Eastwood is in his right behind them hanging the necklace on the mirror as a sign for her to leave the car and runaway with him just like teenagers in love would do. Waw, this movie never stops to amaze me with all the details in it. Both characters never knew what love is and they found it together but not at the right time.There is also the scene where her husband is dying and he asks her if he ever did her wrong and she smiles knowing that she had taken the right choice by staying with her family. That's when duty calls and love no matter how big it is fails to surpass doing what's right.And believe me there is so much more to the movie and no matter how much has been said in the reviews, there is still more.
It's a movie about how it's okay to cheat on your spouse if you're bored in your marriage..

reviews.review_title: Should please admirers of the book...and Streep gives it added sparkle
reviews.content: Unfulfilled housewife in Iowa (Meryl Streep) has a brief but passionate affair with a photographer passing through town (Clint Eastwood, who also directed). Sterling adaptation of Robert James Waller's phenomenal bestseller, which had romantics gushing from coast to coast, though one which leans heavily on the stars for much of its charm; the story is unnecessarily framed in corny past-and-present structure, and Eastwood lays it all out in the most elementary of terms. The pacing is much too careful and lethargic, however Clint's chemistry with a curiously cast yet exceptional Meryl Streep is captured well. Her performance alone makes the picture worth-seeing; soft, yet earthy and gutsy--and with a convincing Italian accent--Streep manages a full-blooded character, someone with whom audiences can instantly identify. She makes "Bridges" a memorable entertainment, if not quite an eventful one. ** from ****

This film portrays a beautiful love story with which we get fascinated if we want so. If we forget that this is just another story, with different characters, different situations, a different time and made in 1995 instead of 1940, we could even say that it's a modern Casablanca. The main elements are there: An impossible love, lovers took apart by almost irresistible forces, and several common scenes: The rain scene, the appearance of Eastwood in the rain (similar to the appearance of Ingrid Bergman at Rick's cafe in the night)... In Casablanca they always would have Paris, in The Bridges of Madison County they always would have Iowa...Thus, in my opinion, this film borrows several elements from Casablanca, but not to copy them, but to incorporate them into a different story.This film is beautiful. Eastwood and Streep are near perfect, to the point that we forget their physical appearances to reach their feelings. We are able to see the inner beauty they have found in each other and get captivated by the atmosphere. There is a fantastic use of light which fits perfectly with every situation, and the music is quite good.When the film finishes, you find yourself in deep melancholy. My conclusion is that Clint Eastwood is better director than actor, I guess.My rating is 9 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Clint Eastwood and Meryl Streep did a magnificent job!
reviews.content: I think most people who've seen this film would agree--the cuts to present day son and daughter dealing with their miserable little lives does nothing but take away from the beauty of this forbidden love story.Clint Eastwood and Meryl Streep did a magnificent job at putting together a joint performance that made me cry as much as the book. That little tidbit might scare away some male viewers, but let me assure it's not a sappy love story. Even my husband thought this was a "really good movie." We are absorbed by these two characters and feel their chemistry almost immediately. By the time we remember that there's a family out there to consider, it's too late. We're dug in deep and feel the pain of having to choose between what's always been and what could be. And it's a powerful moment when that choice is finally made

I remember seeing this movie dating my wife about 5 years ago. We rented it and thought it would the perfect ending to an otherwise wonderful date.  We knew nothing about it, but with Clint & Merril in it, we thought it couldn't be that bad.After viewing it, I was depressed because to me, despite all of its acting and technical expertise, it was still a movie about adultery - not necessarily a subject you want to dwell on when you are thinking about marrying someone.What I disliked most about the movie was that it tried to make a case where adultery is acceptable.  It tried to make it beautiful (and it must have succeeded.  I've talked with many women who've seen it and many said that they would have ran off with Clint's character - what's going on in their homes huh?). How can adultery be beautiful, especially when the husband was not abusive or an adulterer himself? We are after all human and make mistakes, but the movie did not portray the affair that way.
Although the film put a serious damper on my evening, I still got married and it's been great!

You just have to love Clint cause he knows how to tell a story. Beautiful tiny details make this movie so watchable and you can smell romantic atmosphere, feel the actors and live their joy, sadness and love. Recommend it hundred times!!

reviews.review_title: A film every hopeless romantic will love
reviews.content: A tale of two people who meet and have an intense couple of days together which will affect them for the rest of their lives. With a soundtrack of great jazz music and excellent performances from Meryl Streep and Clint Eastwood, this film makes you wish so much for an experience like this but oh the suffering it also brings to these two people. The scene at the traffic lights near the end breaks my heart every time even though I've now seen this film at least 10 times. The piano love theme music, written by Clint, is enough to bring me to tears every time I hear it. So, if you have never seen this - indulge yourself but be warned, it will move you to tears unless you have a heart of stone!

I am a big slob for love-romances, but I must admit I was surfing the web while KCET presented this film.I am a huge fan of Meryl Streep ("Francesca Johnson") and can tolerate Clint Eastwood ("Robert Kincaid"). Infidelity happens every second in marriage, and the trailer certainly lets you know IMMEDIATELY this is a love-affair between the two leading stars. Please give me some d.r.a.m.a. with love-affairs. Humdrum is every day......I suppose the point that I didn't get excited over is how the "kids" became adjusted to their mother (Streep) wanting to be cremated and her ashes scattered off a bridge. Cremation is an every-day affair, now. And, this story reversed the passion in the family: remember how large farm-families used to be? Farmers were hardly ever too tired to make babies. That "Mom" was the horny one should shock no one, if "Dad" weren't romantic enough to quench "Mom's" roving eye. Most moms are clever enough to realize four days aren't going to erase many years of sacrifice and love.....she made "the right" decision, because she knew she was where she belonged.I shed tears even for happy and beautiful movies - "Bridges" didn't open the spigot for me. Maybe I'll give it look-see at a later date, but right now I wouldn't dash out and purchase a DVD. "STARZ" showed it every day for a week ? Wow ! I like to watch movies I love many times, but that's a bit much for me. I guess I would have loved all that cinemascope landscape and beautiful colors - some of the songs in the score I really love. I also feel great acting can be done in a very simple story, but I didn't find it here. Glad all you guys liked it - I AM one to feel love comes at first-sight - and it can also grow on you - but, "Bridges of Madison County" just didn't turn me on. Sorry -

reviews.review_title: Fantastic performance by Meryl Streep but ...
reviews.content: Streep delivers a fantastic and convincing performance full of subtlety...but the film is paced extremely slow and the flow is constantly broken by the jarring transitions to her present day children reading her diary. The acting in those sequences is strikingly bad and destroys any sense of immersion in the story. A cut of this film without those sequences would be at least one star higher...maybe more since I cannot truly tell if I would have been more drawn into the story without them.

This is like Brief Encounter and Casablanca in that it evokes the agony of having to make choices based upon what you think will make your life bearable, at the expense of losing something wonderful, that then becomes a treasured memory. I'm sure many people have had similar experiences in their lives, maybe not as intense as the one experienced by Francesca and Robert in this film. I agree that the performances were impeccable and the limited sets made the viewer focus on the relationship that was central to the plot. It's a very intense portrayal of a very real emotional dilemma, and I empathised with Francesca's difficult choice. I do think she chose wisely but in a way it was a no-win situation for her. Time does heal and make that pain bearable, and maybe it did for her.It was obvious to me that she chose to become closer to Robert - she invited him into her life, and then she realised the impact of what she had done. It is a cautionary tale in some ways as well - I'm sure a lot of people in that situation would have denied themselves that opportunity. Meryl Streep's performance conveyed every aspect of what her character felt, without words in many cases. Clint Eastwood was also excellent but i couldn't help wishing he had been a bit younger. I don't know how old the characters were in the book.This is one of the few movies that tears my heart out each time I see it as do the English Patient, Schindler's List, and some others. The realism of the emotions is so dramatic that it's impossible to avoid being drawn in. I agree with comments that the cutting away to the "present" with her children reading the diary was unnecessary, but this didn't ruin it for me.

reviews.review_title: Honest emotions, touching story, deeply felt performances...
reviews.content: I put off watching THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY because I expected it to be a lot of sentimental nonsense about two aging fools who fall in love at first sight before the soap suds become thicker and thicker.Well, I was wrong. I have to confess that I was afraid I'd have to put up with another Meryl Streep accent that would leave half of her words unintelligible, but again I was wrong. Streep gets across the Italian ancestry without too heavy an accent and gives a remarkably fine performance, doing so much with her eyes and expressive face that she doesn't even need dialogue. She shows us the pain just below the surface--and the boredom and loneliness of the housewife who yearns for something missing in her marriage relationship.And Clint Eastwood scores too, this time without guns or tough guy lines that we're used to hearing from him. He does an honest, realistic and natural job of acting that makes him seem what he is supposed to be--a traveling photographer with the National Geographic intent on filming some of those lovely New England bridges.The story moves just a little too slowly for comfort at times and this is the only major flaw because it's told in such an honest fashion from beginning to end. Streep's children are extremely well played and their viewpoint is understandable when they discover the diaries she has kept of her four day love affair.Touching and straightforward in its simplicity, there is much to admire about the film. Streep and Eastwood are at their level best. The color photography is a treat and so is the unobtrusive background score.Again, the only real flaw is the length. It's the kind of relationship tale that could have been told just as effectively without scenes that are held too long.

This story about the lowly housewife being left alone home for a few days while her husband and children are away at a state fair in a Neighboring state. Then she is swept off of her feet by a traveling photographer from National Geographic. While being a good movie, the question posed is a way to ask the viewer to condone and accept infidelity. That can never be condoned, accepted, or approved.

reviews.review_title: Lust and Loss in the Corn Fields
reviews.content: An erotic adventure set in rural Iowa in 1965 and later. Seriously bored, unhappily married but quite lusty war bride turned farm wife, Francesca, finds herself alone on her dreary Iowa farm for four days when hubby and the two teenage kids take off with prize steer to the Illinois county fair. She is stuck tending the corn and canning vittles and sometimes flashing the scare crow when it gets windy. She married a soldier turned civilian farmer hoping for a ticket to America and a life of adventure only to get what she considers drudgery in small town USA. Things change when Robert, an aging free range and randy Nat Geo photog bops into morally conservative and gossipy Madison County to take a few snappies of the local covered bridges. In the few scenes that show it, the residents of this town are mostly portrayed as overweight, homely or rude. Robert runs into Francesca when scoping out the bridges and sensing she is willing, presses hard toward the goal from the get go. He regales her with stories of his world travels while probing her about her happiness. This is also shown in several scenes of Robert admiring her back-end on the porch, long looks into her eyes and brushing against her several times. Robert also makes it clear on their first evening together that he has little use for morality or places any value on the traditional family. He is more of an amoral citizen of the world. In a bizarre analogy, he compares his morality to that of wild animals in Africa. Francesca finally bites and the two eventually hook up for four days getting their groove on in the bed, bathtub and beyond. Robert splits town a few days after her hubby and kids return from the fair. Even though he offered to take Francesca with him on his next adventure, she nearly left but instead decided due to a sense of duty to stay at Green Acres than go frolicking with the photog in some jungle.Fast forward a decade and a half later and Francesca's hubby has gone toes up leaving her alone on the farm to wonder about what may have been had she booked out of Iowa with Robert. Fast forward a second time to 1982 and Francesca finds out that Robert is now taking his dirt nap when the UPS man delivers a cardboard box to her home. Turns out that Robert left her his estate consisting of a couple beat up camera, his bracelet and her necklace she gave him in 1965 and a book detailing their four day fling. Old Francesca just got screwed again since that is it, no money, stocks, real estate or precious metals. Just a box of junk barely worthy of ebay. Turns out old Robert had no earning potential. Fast forward one final time to the 1990s and now Francesca is in the bone orchard and her two kids, both bitter losers themselves, discover her infidelity when they find Mom's tawdry journals detailing the love fest and Robert's box of junk. They fight over the situation with the daughter defending her mom's sexual adventures while the son believes old Robert was just getting his Tinder on. Then they both later conclude that Mom was right since she was so unhappy. The final scene is quite interesting with the daughter, wearing the dress Francesca bought for her first night a passion with Robert, stretched out on her Mom's bed in the farmhouse (the same bed ....), calling her husband to ask for a divorce. The apple does not fall far from the tree in Madison County.Moral of this story: Its not the farmer's daughter, but the farmer's wife is where its at.

It isn't often I become in awe of somebody's acting skills, however great they are. Mostly, because the very best acting really shouldn't make an impression of its own. That is its very definition.Case in point: Meryl Streep. It is hard to deny that she is more Goddess than actor to most people, much like Jack Nicholson, she's become an icon unto herself. This regardless of whether you like her or not.Which makes it so much more impressive when Streep pulls off a magic trick of major magnitude: making the audience forget it's actually her. She does so quickly and seemingly effortlessly, which is crucial to the suspension of disbelief required to become involved in this sappy love story. It's no minor feat, considering she's Meryl-f*cking-Streep! (attach as many exclamation points as you like, depending on how gay you are).So, what about the movie itself? Clearly a superior work to the underlying novel, thanks to skillful direction and overall good performances. Definitely moving in a bitter-sweet way. In my opinion, it's just a little too soppy for me to think it's truly great. But despite its being such a blatant tearjerker, it's nevertheless appealing and gripping. Something to cleanse your sinuses and refresh your soul.Kudos especially to Eastwood, who has repeatedly proved himself a far superior director than actor (and that's saying some). But overall, this is Meryl Streep's victory over her own cult status. Halle Berry was right: she must be the best actress of all time.

The closing scene, if your life has seen even a remotely similar path, while devastate you. Combine the premise with the dramatic chops of Meryl Streep and cinematic history is made; as it was.I had little regard for Clint Eastwood as a director; for no cause other than I was ignorant of his body of work. But so much empathy is drawn from the viewer of this film that it must be a credit to his skill. The story is great, certainly, but there are moments after moments of incredible poignancy. There can be no need for a spoiler alert. This is a doomed relationship. Tragedy of Shakespearean dimension. There is a scene as they relax ( more like recuperate) in a bathtub together after lovemaking. The utter unrevealed grief they are experiencing is heartbreaking. You feel it just as profoundly as the characters. That is the point of the film.This one will make a bad ass cry.

I don't get what the hype was about this book or this movie. It was FOUR DAYS of her life, yet decades later, she remembers it like it was yesterday? Please. It was FOUR DAYS. You can't fall in love, true love, with someone in FOUR DAYS and then remember every second of that weekend decades later. I don't buy it.Francesca broke the rules of marriage. There was no reason for her to have an affair. None at all. She brought it all upon herself.And what did the photographer care? He was just passing through town and had ladies like her everywhere. What made her so special? She was a married woman with kids. A true love would not make you break your vows to your husband and take advantage of you in your own home like that. I didn't buy the "love" story at all.This movie is about LUST. Plain and simple. No love. If she would've gotten out of that truck it would've been for lust, not love. And then what? Would it have been forever? Anyone who breaks the vows of marriage does not live "happily ever after". If it wasn't that photographer, it would've been someone else. Anyone who gave her the slightest bit of attention. It just happened to be him.If you are looking for a true love story, this isn't the movie for you.

In the 1960s a somewhat dissatisfied farmers housewife Francesca Johnson (Meryl Streep meets photographer Robert Kincaid (Clint Eastwood). Her husband and kids are away for four days--and they both start to fall in love with each other.This was a big hit in 1995 to everyones surprise. It was just a simple love story but everybody seemed to love it. It IS good. The script is excellent--everybody talks and acts like real people. Nothing is overstated--everything is quiet and subtle allowing the audience to discover the characters for themselves. Eastwood is excellent and Streep is superb--she was justly nominated for an Academy award for this performance. It is very good...but it just fell a little short for me.It moves a little too slow--this doesn't have to run over two hours. I also thought the rainstorm ending was a bit much. It just never connected with me emotionally--I usually cry during movies like this but I was completely dry-eyed during this. So it IS a good movie (I give it a 9) but just didn't completely work for me. Worth catching though.

The Bridges of Madison County definitely highlighted the talents of Clint Eastwood (Robert Kincaid) and especially Meryl Streep (Francesca Johnson) to a nearly flawless performance. I've come accustom over recent years to see how much Eastwood has developed as a director. His films have generated a lot of interest and I think it's because how he manages to pull at our heart strings and convey the sentimentality between characters. 'Bridges of Madison' does just that pulls you in by the chemistry of Streep and Eastwood. It's also the beautiful storyline and how it's told through flash back after the death of Francesca. She leaves a letter to her 2 children explaining her love affair with Robert Kincaid, a man she met some 30 yrs prior. This was her legacy to them, and to share the true meaning of love and sacrifice.

I wonder how many people calling this a romance / love story would be saying the same from the view of the Husband. Also,why would the kids who would have loved both parents, take the news of thier mothers continued infidelity as anything but horrific.
The whole movie is a strange flip on morality where we want the good guys to win.

reviews.review_title: Read the Book? then watch the film.
reviews.content: Sometimes i like to read a book which has been adapted to a film, which i have yet to see. That way i can image the charcters better, and won't be so annoyed when i watch the movie. Of course this also takes away some of the magic of using your imagination.Bridges, is a short book, only 150pgs, but it moved me so much, and i knew why people made such a fuss over it. I then watched the movie, Eastwood, as a director has yet to dissapoint me, and he does far from that with this film.It captures the essence of the book so well, and is a really good adaptation. Ultimately though, i think those who haven't read the book won't gain as much out of it, the movie moved me more so, becasue i knew more about the characters from the book. I felt as if i had just read someone's diary, and was now watching the home video.  So if you are planning to watch this film, becasue you love romance, i recommend to read the book first, it's only a short book, so it won't take long to read -- but it will stay with you for ages.

It was a great film back in the day; now I just want to shoot myself for watching it again.
That's what's up!
Long but beautiful. If you're not a romantic soul adapted for long movies with a deeper meaning, don't watch it.

Quintissential superlative love ballad out of the Love Story mould, only Ali Magraw and Ryan O'Neal have aged somewhat slightly...Yet there are no corny moments in this short story style paperback tale. Yes the Italian accent was good, by the premier classic bard performance of Ms Streep.
